bib.title: The spectral species concept: lights and shadows of a challenging idea
bib.author: Duccio Rocchini and Maria J Santos and Susan Ustin and Jean-Baptiste Feret and Greg Asner and Carl Beierkuhnlein and Michele Dalponte and Hannes Feilhauer and Giles M Foody and Gary N Geller and Thomas W Gillespie and Kate S He and David Kleijn and Pedro J Leitão and Marco Malavasi and Jana Müllerová and Vı́tězslav Moudrý and Harini Nagendra and Signe Normand and Carlo Ricotta and Michael E Schaepman and Sebastian Schmidtlein and Andrew K Skidmore and Petra Šímová and Michele Torresani and Philip A Townsend and Woody Turner and Petteri Vihervaara and Martin Wegmann and Jonathan Lenoir
bib.abstract: Biodiversity monitoring is a challenge especially for large or isolated areas such as entire continents or remote mountain summits or islands, respectively. Nowadays, remote sensing technology such as spaceborne and airborne sensors provide images over large and remote areas that incorporate wavelengths, and thus information, that cannot be seen with the human eye. This is also now accomplished at unprecedented spatial resolutions, defined by the pixel size of images, achieving less than a meter for some satellite images and just centimeters for drone and aircraft imagery. Thanks to different modelling techniques relying on this data-rich information repeatedly provided over time as contiguous gridded layers, it is now possible to remotely assess biodiversity changes in space and time over different spatial scales and variable dimensions.
